poem:
"Ode to a Coastline Song"

Beneath an old schoolhouse Donegal,
In Atlantic whispers, hear him call,
Oisín, once lost, now found in grace,
Draws music from the sea and place.

Dissonance from cities fades,
Replaced by seagulls' rhythmic parades.
Taste the salt, feel the breeze,
In every note and harmony, he frees.

From Americana to salt-tinged strands,
The poet's voice, in his own hands.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Oisín Leech: Cold Sea review – you can almost taste the salt After several albums as half of the Irish Americana duo the Lost Brothers – each recorded in a different US city – Oisín Leech has brought it all back home with a solo effort recorded in an old schoolhouse on the wild coast of County Donegal. It’s a striking contrast to his work with “the Losties”, as he calls them, shorn of the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
